awd_titl_txt: Mechanical properties and thermomechanical processing of metallic glasses -- the role of elemental distributions and size-dependent properties of shear transformation zones
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract

Molten metallic alloys of certain compositions can be frozen to produce metallic glasses. In contrast to conventional metals, which are crystalline, the atomic arrangements in metallic glasses exhibit significant disorder. The high strength and elasticity of metallic glasses make them attractive for applications in medical and other mechanical devices, as well as sporting goods. However, they exhibit limited ductility and toughness, which can lead to catastrophic fracture. In crystalline materials, heat and deformation treatment are routinely used for property improvement, and the associated mechanisms have been understood for many years. A parallel understanding of the atomic-scale rearrangements in metallic glasses is a scientific challenge, since the baseline arrangements are not known. However, such an understanding is crucial to improving their properties. A recently developed method of characterizing  small atomic clusters  called shear transformation zones (STZs), undergo shape change as a result of deformation in a metallic glass, is used in this research. Analysis of time-dependent shape recovery reveals distinct signatures of STZs, resolved by the number of atoms they comprise. Critical experiments will be performed to explain previous experimental observations. The STZ dynamics will be compared between similar alloys that differ in their ductility. Atom-probe tomography, a method that can yield atomic-scale composition mapping, will be used to determine the role of potentially heterogeneous chemical composition, and its correlation with the STZ population. The expected results include realistic input into simulations of macroscopic behavior. The insights gained will help interpret a range of past experimental results, and assist future development of ductile alloys. The proposed work will promote the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, who will learn materials fundamentals, develop the ability to plan and conduct experiments and modeling, and learn to communicate their results. The PI and graduate students will participate in high-school visits in under-resourced parts of the state of Michigan.


Technical Abstract

Metallic glasses exhibit high strength and stiffness, making them attractive for structural applications. However, flow localization often leads to catastrophic failure at a shear band. As in crystalline materials, thermo-mechanical treatment can improve their properties. In contrast to crystalline materials, an atomic level understanding of mechanical properties of metallic glasses and their response to thermo-mechanical treatment is still lacking. Plastic deformation of metallic glasses is accommodated by thermally activated shear of atomic clusters, known as shear transformation zones (STZs). Because there is no known mechanism for imaging STZs, their microscopic properties had been studied mostly in physical analogues and numerical models, which cover a limited dynamic range of time. Recently, the anelastic relaxation kinetics of different metallic glasses have been measured.  These measurements reveal an atomically quantized hierarchy of STZs, resolved by the number of atoms they comprise. The shape of the size-density distributions of potential STZs, obtained from the spectra, varies significantly with the alloy. The proposed work is aimed at gaining an atomic scale understanding of how the size distribution of potential STZs a) correlates with ductility, stored enthalpy and chemical heterogeneity; b) varies between conventional metallic glasses and those with intense high-frequency (beta) mechanical relaxations, which have been shown to be ductile; c) is affected by thermomechanical treatment, including thermal cycling, cyclic and elastostatic deformation. Using a combination of quasi-static and cyclic experiments, more than eight orders of magnitude in relaxation time will be covered. Relaxation-time spectra will be computed from the data. The stored enthalpy will be determined by differential scanning calorimetry. Atom-probe tomography (APT) will be used to identify deviations from random elemental distributions, including size distributions of clusters enriched in an alloying element. Correlating the APT results with the size distribution of potential STZs will elucidate the role of local chemistry in shear transformations. Experimental input will be provided for mesoscopic simulations of macroscopic behavior. The proposed work will enhance the atomic-scale understanding of processing and deformation of metallic glasses, bringing the community's understanding of metallic glass properties closer to that for crystalline metals. The results will assist the future development of ductile alloys, thus impacting future technology. Graduate and undergraduate students will a) learn materials fundamentals; b) develop the ability to plan and conduct combined experiments and modeling, and to communicate their results. The PI and/or graduate students will participate in high-school visits in under-resourced parts of the state of Michigan.

por.por_cntn:
Metallic glasses are metal alloys that, unlike all metallic materials encountered in daily life, are not crystalline. The atoms of which they consist are arranged in a disordered manner, similar to the melt. They have a variety of attractive properties, among them high stiffness and high elastic strain. The combination of these two properties makes them useful spring material as they can store a high amount of elastic energy. The Achilles heel of metallic glasses is that they exhibit very limited plastic deformation – they fail catastrophically, in a macroscopically brittle manner. Unlike crystalline materials, which are typically at thermodynamic equilibrium, the structure of metallic glasses evolves in time – it is dependent on the temperature and mechanical history. Many properties are very sensitive to the structure. Structural relaxation by aging leads, e.g., to embrittlement, and much attention has been given in recent years to rejuvenation -- reversal of this effect -- by static stress or cycling between cryogenic and room temperature.

Although metallic glasses have been known to researchers for decades, much has yet to be uncovered about the evolution of their structure, and with it, of their properties. The theoretical and experimental tools that have enabled researchers to understand crystalline materials are often not applicable to glasses. During prior years, we developed an approach that allows for a detailed analysis of deformation kinetics. It is based on anelastic (time dependent and reversible) deformation experiments over time scales that exceed a year. A previously proposed model, based on physical analogs, describes the deformation in terms of shear transformation zones (STZs) – atomic clusters that undergo irreversible shape change while the matrix that surrounds them deforms elastically. Under external stress, STZs form to accommodate the shape change. When the external stress is removed, the STZs revert to their original, approximately spherical, shape. Both processes are time dependent. We had observed that unlike prevailing assumptions, there is a spectrum of STZ sizes. The larger they are, the slower their response. An additional atom in an STZ corresponds to a deformation rate lower by a factor of 10. Instead of observing a simple exponential response that would correspond to a single size, we observe the sum of multiple exponential curves, with evolution over time scales ranging from seconds to years. The measured curves provide a wealth of information, including the spectrum and volume fraction of sizes of potential STZs, (i.e., clusters capable of undergoing a shear transformation). 

During the present grant period, we used the method we had developed to characterize differences among metallic glasses – those due to composition differences and others due to structural relaxation or rejuvenation. It had been observed that substitution of copper for nickel in a metallic glass leads to greater plasticity. Our results provide the first explanation of this effect – with the presence of copper, the volume fraction of small STZ is larger, and these can respond to applied stress faster, thus avoiding stress concentration and fracture. Much attention has been given in the literature to what has been described as distinct relaxations, slow (alpha) and fast (beta). We show that unlike in polymeric materials, alpha and beta relaxations in metallic glasses differ in quantitative properties but correspond to the same mechanism. Our data provide atomic-scale information on structural relaxation and rejuvenation: aging reduces the number of potential STZs and also leads to an increase in the rate at which they respond to stress. Rejuvenation by temperature cycling reverses to the slowing of the rate but does not restore the reduction in the number. The transformation strain, i.e., the degree of deformation, of an STZ has been determined from nonlinear experiments, conducted at high strain, to be 0.18. This confirms estimated values used in the past. Finally, much of the literature involves using the stretched exponent to analyze data that originate from exponential relaxation with multiple time constants, i.e., rates. This approach is phenomenological and does not rely on a physical model. We show, in fact, that it leads to inconsistencies.

The results obtained, and the insights they lead to, on the structure-property relationships of metallic glasses are expected to contribute to alloy development and improved performance for mechanical applications.

The research performed under this grant informed a new graduate course on glasses developed and taught by the PI. Students involved in research funded by the grant:  A female graduate student received her Ph.D. and is currently an assistant professor. Another student received his master’s degree and is now pursuing his Ph.D. at a peer institution. A minority undergraduate student contributed to and was co-author of several publication funded by this grant. He competed successfully for several prestigious graduate fellowships and is pursuing his Ph.D. at a peer institution. He benefited greatly from mentoring by the Ph.D. student.
